comments:
CDT I200703190600
1. Create a Makefile C++ project with no toolchain.
2. Open C/C++ Project path in project properties.

Include path table lists 6 standard include directories and does not provide any way to get rid of them. "No toolchain" option should not put anything in the include path.
Please try to fix this for M6 since this is a regression from the old project model.

I think I know how to fix this. Will do.

Mikhail

This is now fixed for the "No ToolChain", i.e. it is no possible remove the automatically discovered options.
NOTE: you will need to re-create your curently created "No Tool-Chain" projects to enable this.

The built-in values can also be removed for any other tool-chains in case the tool-chain definition cupports this.

Closing the bug.. Please verify.

Mikhail
Everything works, but an attempt to delete the very last include directory brings all directories back.
The deleted includes, although not shown in project properties, still appear in C/C++ Projects view under Includes folder.

(In reply to comment #4)
> Everything works, but an attempt to delete the very last include directory
> brings all directories back.
This should be fixed with the latest sources from HEAD. Do you still see this problem?

(In reply to comment #10)
Are you using the sources from HEAD?
Could you attach a stack-trace?

I don't think this could be caused by the restore mechanism directly since it contains an explicit check for the tool and option parent equality and should never call remove for the non-tool option.

Mikhail

I am indeed using the sources from HEAD, the toolchain in question is the GNU Cygwin toolchain (cdt.managedbuild.toolchain.gnu.cygwin.base).

(In reply to comment #12)
You are right. I've fixe this. The removeOption now does not throw an IllegalArgumentException.

Thanks for caching this.

Mikhail

With HEAD:
Deletion of the last include now works, but the problem mentioned in comment #5 did not go away.

Created an attachment (id=62151)
Project file

As I can see from the project file, you still have the built-ins undefined for the GNU C++ language (See Comment# 7) Please rty undefining (remove) built-ins for all languages (i.e. GNU C and GNU C++ in the "No Tool-chain" case)

Mikhail

(In reply to comment #16)
> As I can see from the project file, you still have the built-ins undefined for
> the GNU C++ language
Sorry, what I meant to say is that you still have built-ins DEFINED

Mikhail

(In reply to comment #16)

Where is that in UI?

(In reply to comment #18)
> (In reply to comment #16)
> 
> Where is that in UI?
Hi Sergey,

It is in "Includes" tab of the "C/C++ Project Paths & symbols" page.
Note the "Content types" pane on the left of that tab. Selecting the source type will display you include settings for that type.

I guess we sould make some enhancements in UI to allow removing/adding settings for all source types simultaneously and probably display some message in UI warning users that the settings are applied/displayed only for the selected source type.
Oleg, could you take a look into this?

Thanks,
Mikhail
The "Content types" pane in my case is empty. In fact, it doesn't even have a caption. I wouldn't have guessed what it is without you mentioning that it's the pane on the left.

Could you attache a complete sample project that shows this behavior (i.e. not only the .cproject file but the complete project directory)?

Thanks,
Mikhail
